importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The menopause support group at the Harpurhey Neighbourhood Centre began in September 2024, marking the start of a vital community initiative to address menopause-related symptoms and stigma.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The initiative started in 2024 and continues into 2025, showing a sustained effort to expand and sustain menopause support across Manchester, with plans for broader rollout.

keyTakeAways: Menopause symptoms such as anxiety, loneliness, 'brain fog,' and emotional instability are often misinterpreted as mental health issues or signs of losing one's mind, especially post-Covid.
The menopause hub in Manchester provides a safe, supportive environment for women to discuss symptoms, share experiences, and access accurate information, reducing stigma.
Participants report significant improvements in mental health, confidence, and quality of life, with many transitioning from survival to thriving.
The model is being recognized by the NHS Greater Manchester Integrated Care system and is set to expand beyond Manchester.
Women are being empowered through education and peer support, with some becoming 'menopause champions' to help break the silence and support others.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A women's menopause support group launched in September 2024 at the Harpurhey Neighbourhood Centre in Manchester has become a vital lifeline for women experiencing anxiety, confusion, and emotional distress linked to menopause. Initiated by Leonie Painter after her own struggles, the group offers peer support, accurate information, and expert talks on menopause symptoms, hormone therapy, mental health, and lifestyle. Participants like Liza Davies and Deena Banister report significant improvements in well-being, with many transitioning from survival to thriving. The initiative, funded by Manchester City Council and Jigsaw Housing through the Winning Hearts and Minds program, is now being recognized by the NHS Greater Manchester Integrated Care system and is set to expand across the region, addressing stigma and transforming how women access care during menopause.
title: I thought I was losing my mind but it was the menopause
